section.note: Although relationships in general are discussed in , the IS-A relationship(s) are so fundamental to using the Workbench, not just for adding and modifying concepts, but for "classification", "refset" construction and other processing, that they have been singled out for special consideration here.

body.section: is aIs aThe Workbench "is a"The IHTSDO workbench itself, incorporates some internal hierarchies of concepts, often described as metadata concepts or auxiliary concepts, which exist independently of any given terminology under consideration for authoring, editing or processing by workbench users. Although they may not be included in a final terminology distribution, they are needed for the functioning of many aspects of the workbench. Some concepts covered by the inbuilt workbench hierarchies include users, user roles, queues, paths and more. In particular, these auxiliary metadata hierarchies are built upon, and gain additional definition from the Workbench's inbuilt "is a" relationship (all lower case). This is a concept in the Terminology Auxiliary concept hierarchy and has a fully qualified name "is a (relationship type)".

Is ais aThe SNOMED "Is a"The IHTSDO workbench supports terminology IS-A relationships other than the in-built "is a". In particular, SNOMED CT incorporates its own IS-A relationship, with a preferred term of "Is a" and fully specified name of "Is a (attribute)". It is very important to be aware of these two IS-A relationships, and where they are used, particularly with respect to their use in various preference settings. The primary preference setting for determining IS_A use is the Edit -> Defaults -> Default relationship type, as shown in . Preference Panel - edit default settings
Other important preferences to watch out for with respect to IS-A relationships are:
edit -> Rel type -> Relationship types for pop up
classifier -> Classification 'Is a'
